However, the dehydration causes severe coking at strong acid sites on the surface of catalyst. Molybdenum-vanadium oxide supported on calcium oxide-intercalated montmorillonite (MoV-CaMMT) was prepared by oxalate anion intercalation followed by impregnation. MoV-CaMMT displayed the best catalytic performance of 86.5% glycerol conversion and good stability in 5 h. Correlating the results of XRD, XPS and TG analysis, it can be demonstrated that the addition of CaO in the catalyst preparation is conducive to the crystallization and dispersion of vanadium oxides, and reduces the acid strength, while the presence of a few vanadium dioxide and the stable conversion of V4+ and V5+ are the reasons for enhancing coking-resistance of MoV-CaMMT. Additionally, NH3-TPD analysis proved the coexistence of weak and strong acid sites in MoVOx, which are conducive to the formation of acetol. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Glycerol Allyl alcohol Deoxydehydration Coking-resistance Montmorillonite Molybdenum-vanadium Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Crude glycerol is the main by-product (about 10% of biodiesel) in biodiesel production by transesterification [1]. With the rapid increase of biodiesel production, crude glycerol production has been simultaneously increased approximately to 50 billion liters in year 2021 [2]. However, the traditional glycerol industry cannot consume the increasing production of crude glycerol and this obviously causes lower the price of crude glycerol [3]. Finding an innovative approach to convert crude glycerol into other high value-added chemicals through chemical reaction can not only broaden the way of glycerol consumption but also improve the comprehensive income of biodiesel [3–5]. Allyl alcohol is an intermediate product obtained by deoxydehydration (DODH) or dehydration and hydrogen transfer of glycerol. The DODH process of glycerol induced by formic acid enables glycerol to continuously produce allyl alcohol in the liquid phase, and then convert to acrylic acid through the subsequent oxidation reaction [6]. Tshibalonza et al. [7] designed a microfluidic reaction device for continuous-flow glycerol deoxidation and dehydration at high temperature (300 ℃). Although the glycerol conversion and allyl alcohol selectivity obtained by liquid phase reaction of the microfluidic device were not as high as those obtained by formic acid induced glycerol deoxidation and dehydration process operated by distillation, this method has the characteristics of short reaction time (1–6 min) and easy operation. Deoxydehydration with formic acid is difficult to use in the industry due to its poor atomic economy, which requires complex distillation and purification of allyl alcohol. Also, formic acid is converted into water and carbon dioxide during repeated heating, cooling, and replenishing of the solution [8,9]. Glycerol can be converted to acrolein, propanal and allyl alcohol at 165 ℃ under the catalysis of rhenium methyl trioxide (CH3ReO3, MTO) [9]. The selectivity of allyl alcohol can be enhanced from 72% to either 75% or 97% with the addition of a small quantity of potassium chloride or octanol respectively [10]. MTO showed excellent catalytic performance in the catalytic deoxidation and dehydration of glycerol in organic and aqueous solvents. Due to the high price of MTO, Canale et al. [11] evaluated the catalytic activity of relatively inexpensive rhenium derivatives (ReO3, NH4ReO4, Re2(CO)10, Cp*ReO3) in glycerol dehydrating oxidation reactions. It is found that MTO and ReO3 can catalyze glycerol deoxidation and dehydration at comparatively low temperature (140 ℃), while other rhenium catalysts are active at higher temperatures (170 ℃). Although rhenium catalysts are effective for the DODH reaction of glycerol, their high cost and instability make it difficult to commercialize. In addition to rhenium catalysts that exhibit unique activity in DODH, vanadium and molybdenum catalysts have been reported for the catalysis of glycerol DODH to produce allyl alcohol without additional hydrogen sources. Allan et al. [12] found that NH4VO3 was an effective catalyst for glycerol deoxidation and dehydration, and the yield of allyl alcohol produced by the reaction was higher than that of MTO. In the experiment of deuterated glycerol as reactant, it was confirmed that glycerol was converted to allyl alcohol by NH4VO3. Besides, (NH4)6Mo7O24 and other molybdenum compounds can be potentially fungible for the rhenium in the catalytic DODH of aliphatic diols into the corresponding alkenes [13]. The DODH of glycerol yields allyl alcohol, which undergoes subsequent molybdenum catalyzed deoxygenation to propylene driven by oxidation of isopropanol [14]. Both solid acid and metal oxide catalysts have demonstrated excellent catalytic activity in glycerol dehydration, oxidation, deoxydehydration and other reactions, but many catalysts fail to counter the problem of loss of activity after carbon deposition [15]. In the process of catalytic glycerol oxidation and dehydration, the catalyst will be deactivated due to changes in physical structure, active site poisoning, carbon accumulation, thermal decomposition of active substances and other reasons; the main reason is that in the reaction between glycerol, acrolein and acetol molecules, there is a high chance of polymerization which may form a large number of carbon deposits an coke [16–18]. Thus, it has of great importance to prepare coking-resistance catalysts by controlling the acid strength and acidity types of catalysts (Brønsted and Lewis acid sites) to avoid the precursor polycondensation and other secondary reactions involved in the formation of coke [15,19]. The coke-deposition behavior of catalysts can also be affected by improving the dispersion of the supported metal oxides or adding additional active components [20,21]. And the addition of precious metals (Ru, Pd, Pt) to solid acid catalysts is conducive to inhibiting catalyst deactivation, because the carbon substrate is introduced into the lattice of precious metals and effectively reduces deposition on the catalyst [22]. The addition of CeO2 increased the dispersion of nickel, and Mg, Ba, and Ca promoters increased the basicity of the nickel-based catalyst. these are useful for coking-resistance in dry reforming of methane [23,24]. Ou et al. found the addition of alkaline oxides (CaO, MgO, ZnO and La2O3) facilitate the adsorption and activation of CO2 and accelerate the elimination of carbon deposition by providing more oxygen species [25]. In addition, the catalyst doped with vanadium species showed better catalytic activity in the dry reforming process of methane, and the hydrogen yield was increased under dilution conditions, and the coking-resistance of the catalyst was enhanced after combining with calcium carbonate[26]. Therefore, there may be synergistic effects of vanadium and calcium in acid catalysts, precious metal catalysts or metal oxide catalysts to enhance their coking-resistance. Additionally, the impact of free H+ for the acid-activated montmorillonite (MMT) on glycerol dehydration was insignificant, whereas appropriate medium-strong acidic sites exhibited remarkable catalytic activity towards glycerol conversion [27]. Dolomite or calcium oxide (CaO) catalysts can be used as basic catalysts for steam reforming [28], catalytic cracking [29], deoxidation and dehydration[30]. Therefore, it remains to be studied how to add basic sites to acid catalysts with strong acid sites to prepare the catalyst with appropriate acidity and basic sites to catalyze the products of glycerol dehydration or dehydration oxidation reaction and the catalytic mechanism. And whether basic species can be added, which usually cannot coexist with basic species to tune enhancing coking-resistance and stability of catalyst remain elusive. Molybdenum-vanadium (Mo/V) compounds have been shown to catalyze the deoxidation and dehydration of glycerol to produce allyl alcohol directly, but the coking of the catalysts is not considered in these experiments. In this work, we identified catalyst materials with optimal Mo/V ratios for glycerol deoxidation and dehydration, and assessed the activity and coking-resistance of these catalysts impregnated with Mo/V (at optimal ratios) supported by varying amounts of CaO-intercalated MMT. Additionally, we investigated the mechanism behind their coking-resistance. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Glycerol (AR, 99 %), ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O) and NH4VO3 were purchased from Aladdin. H3PO4 (85 wt % in H2O) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Na-MMT (Na-MMT) was purchased from Qingyang, Anhui, China. CaO (AR, 98 %) and oxalic acid (AR, 99 %) was purchased from Shanghai Lingfeng. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Acidified Na-MMT Na-MMT was acidified by 1 mol/L H3PO4 aqueous solution. Specifically, a mixture of Na-MMT and 1 mol/L H3PO4 aqueous solution (mass ratio of 1: 19) was placed in a round-bottomed flask and the mixture was stirred at 80 ℃ for 4 h. After the mixture cooling down to room temperature, the mixture was separated by centrifugation at 4000 rpm for 5 min. The obtained solid product was washed with deionized water to neutrality and then dried at 80 ℃ for 24 h to obtain acid-activated MMT. Ammonium metavanadate was dissolved in oxalic acid solution to obtain a vanadium oxalate complex solution, which was then mixed with calcium-containing compounds and acidified MMT for 6 h. After standing, ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate was added and impregnated for 24 h before being heated in an oven and muffle furnace at temperatures ranging from 500 ℃ to 800 ℃ to burn off calcium oxalate. 2.2.2 CaO-intercalated montmorillonite (CaxMMT, x is the loading amount of CaO) CaxMMT: a stipulated amount of oxalic acid (0.225 g) with an equal molar ratio of CaO (0.25 g) was placed in 50 mL beaker, then 15 mL deionized water was poured into the beaker to dissolve oxalic acid solution. Then, 5 g of acidified MMT was added into oxalic acid solution and stirred for 2 h at room temperature. Subsequently, 0.25 g of CaO was added and stir for another 2 h. The mixed solution was then poured into the evaporating dish and dried in the oven at 80 ℃ for 24 h, followed by calcination at 500 ℃ at 5 ℃/min in a muffle furnace for 4 h and then at 800 ℃ for 1 h to obtain Ca5MMT. Ca1MMT, Ca2MMT, Ca3MMT and Ca4MMT catalysts were also prepared by changing the molar ratios of CaO and oxalic acid. 2.2.3 Preparation of MoV/CaO intercalated MMT (MoxVy-CazMMT, x and y are the ratio of vanadium/molybdenum, while z is the additive amount of CaO) On the basis of CaxMMT, MoxVy-CazMMT was prepared by an impregnation method. In this procedure, the total impregnated vanadium molybdenum of 5 wt % and the molar ratio of vanadium molybdenum of 8: 2, 1 wt % of CaO were taken as examples: a weighed amount (0.12 g) of oxalic acid was placed into a 50 mL beaker and then dissolved by adding 15 mL of deionized water and stirred. Then, 0.043 g of ammonium metadadate was added into the prepared oxalic acid solution, stir until completely dissolved to obtain the oxalate complex solution. Subsequently, a 3 g of acidified MMT and 0.03 g of CaO were added into the vanadium oxalate complex solution, stirred for 4 h, then allowed to stand for 12 h at room temperature. Then adding 0.29 g ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate, the mixture was agitated for 6 h, impregnating for 24 h, and put them in oven at 80 ℃ for drying. After being completely dried, the product was placed into a Muffle furnace and calcined at 500 ℃ with the heating rate of 5 ℃/min for 4 h and then at 800 ℃ for 1 h. After grinding and sifting to 60–80 mesh, Mo8V2-Ca1MMT catalysts were obtained and stored for further use. Mo8V2-Ca2MMT, Mo8V2-Ca3MMT and Mo8V2-Ca4MMT catalysts were also prepared using the same procedure by changing the amount of CaO to 0.06, 0.09, 0.12 and 0.15 g, respectively. 2.3 Catalytic conversion of glycerol The conversion of glycerol using these catalysts was carried out in a fixed-bed flow reactor for 5 h at the reaction temperature of 320 ℃ under atmospheric pressure. The 20 wt% glycerol aqueous solution was used as a feedstock and fed to the reactor with a syringe pump at a rate of 0.1 mL/min. The products were collected for every 1 h after condensation and analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) (GC-2014; Shimadzu Co. The related elemental distribution was analyzed with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS, Oxford Ultim Max 65). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and morphology of MoV-CaMMTcatalysts The XRD patterns of the CaO-intercalated MMT samples (CaxMMT) shows an intense peak of MMT ( Fig. 1 (a)). The peaks at 2θ = 6.9°, 19.7°, 63°were due to the (001), (020), (060) planes of MMT [31,32]. Moreover, the presence of purity in MMT leads to the peak of quartz (2θ = 21.8°, 2θ = 28°, and 2θ = 36°) [32]. The peaks of (001) crystal surface of CaxMMT at 1, 3 and 5 wt% are located at 2θ = 9.1°, 2θ = 8.8° and 2θ = 8.5°, respectively. The corresponding lamellar spacing of MMT is d001 = 0.97 nm, d001 = 1.00 nm and d001 = 1.03 nm, respectively. Meanwhile, the peaks of CaO (2θ = 28°, 2θ = 35.7° and 2θ = 56.7°) and calcium carbonate (2θ = 31°) appear in the XRD patterns of CaxMMT [33]. It shows that calcium oxalate is not completely decomposed into CaO in the process of calcination of calcium oxalate at high temperature, and partial calcium carbonate is produced. The spacing of CaMMT layers was found to be directly affected by the content of CaO. V-MMT and V-Ca2MMT, V-Ca4MMT and V-Ca6MMT samples all exhibited peaks at 2θ = 16.4° on the (003) crystal surface of MMT and the peak 2θ = 20.5° on the (100) crystal surface. In addition, there are also V2O5 peaks at 2θ = 26.4° and 2θ = 31.2° (Fig. 1 (b)). The diffraction peak at 2θ = 26.4°, corresponding to the (301) crystal surface of V2O5 in V-MMT, becomes sharper in V-CaMMT, which indicates that the presence of CaO is conducive to the perfection of V2O5 crystallization and the enlargement of grain size to some extent [34]. The intensity of peak 2θ = 26.4° of V2O5 decreases with the increase of CaO content, which is caused by the over population of V2O5, CaO and CaCO3 species on the surface of MMT. Fig. 1 (c) displayed all the characteristic diffraction peaks of V2O5 and MO3 in the diffractogram of the catalyst samples. The characteristic diffraction peaks of V2O5 are found at 2θ = 25.3° and 2θ = 31.2°, and the characteristic diffraction peaks for (040) and (140) plane of MO3 are obtained at 2θ = 23.1° and 2θ = 26.3°, respectively (Fig. 1 (c)). FT-IR spectra of 5 wt% MoV-CaMMT catalyst prepared by the intercalation method ( Fig. 2), and the infrared absorption bands corresponding to different functional groups. According to the infrared absorption spectra of Na-MMT (Fig. 2 (a)), the 462 cm-1 and 523 cm-1 bands correspond to the Si–O–Si bend vibration and Al–O–Si bend vibration of MMT structure, respectively [35]. And 788 cm-1 and 1041 cm-1 correspond to Si–O–Si stretches in silico-oxygen tetrahedron structure [36]. Meanwhile, the 916 cm-1 peak corresponds to Al–O–(OH)–Al stretching vibration in MMT structure [37]; 3417 cm-1 corresponds to Si–OH stretches vibration [37]. In addition, 1632 cm-1 and 3612 cm-1 correspond to the bending and stretching vibrations of –OH of adsorbed water molecules of MMT respectively. Among them, 1637 cm-1, 1650 cm-1 and 3626 cm-1 are the infrared absorption bands of carbonate and calcium oxide, respectively [38]. SEM analysis showed that the MoV-MMT catalyst ( Fig. 3 (a, b)) has a smooth surface, and particles of carbonate and Mo/V oxides can also be seen [39–41]. From Fig. 3 (b), the stacking structure of MMT layers can be observed [42]. With the increase of CaO content, the surface of the catalyst became rougher due to the increase of oxide particles. The surface of the V-CazMMT containing 5 wt % CaO was covered by oxide, and the agglomeration of CaO and Mo/V oxide particles was obvious, which was consistent with the XRD analysis. 3.2 Activity and coking studies over the MoV-CaMMT catalyst 3.2.1 Effects of different molar ratios and loading amounts of Mo/V From the characterization results and discussion above, the optimum molybdenum-vanadium molar ratio was Mo/(Mo+V)= 8, that is, Mo8V2-MMT catalyst, which reached the highest catalytic glycerol conversion within 3 h, and the corresponding selectivities of allyl alcohol and acrolein were 37.9 % and 30.6 % ( Fig. 4 (a)). The highest glycerol conversion and allyl alcohol selectivity of 5 wt% Mo8V2-MMT might be ascribed to the appropriate MoVOx phase formed by the appropriate Mo/V ratio [43]. In this regard, the existence of MoVOx phase is beneficial to activate the C–H bond of light olefin and thus enhance the selective oxidation ability of catalyst [44]. The catalytic glycerol conversion rate of Mo8V2-MMT catalyst firstly increased and then decreased with the total impregnation amount of Mo/V oxides in the range of 2.5–10 wt% (Fig. 4 (b)). Glycerol conversion was increased with increasing Mo/V loading from 2.5 wt% to 7.5 wt%, but when the impregnation amount of catalyst was increased to 10 wt%, the maximum glycerol conversion was found to be 64.7%. This might be happened due to covering of the Brønsted acid sites by the excessive Mo/V oxides, thus consequently declined acrolein selectivity with decreasing glycerol conversion [14]. The catalyst activity reached the highest when the total amount of Mo/V oxide impregnation was 7.5 wt %, affording glycerol conversion of 85.7% and the selectivity of allyl alcohol and acrolein was 34.5% and 32.9%, respectively. The maximum glycerol conversion of 5 wt% Mo8V2-MMT catalyst is 81.6% and the selectivity of allyl alcohol and acrolein is 30.6% and 37.9%, respectively. The catalytic performance of 5 wt% Mo8V2-MMT catalyst is slightly lower than that of 7.5 wt %. Although 7.5 wt % Mo8V2-MMT has the best glycerol conversion and allyl alcohol selectivity compared with 5 wt % Mo8V2-MMT, 7.5 wt % Mo8V2-MMT has more active sites and more easily to undergo inactivation. 3.2.2 Effects of calcium content The glycerol reaction catalyzed by Mo2V8-CaMMT catalyst involves a variety of reactions, including dehydration of glycerol at the Brønsted acid site to acrolein, dehydration of glycerol at the Lewis acid site to acetol, or the deoxidation dehydration of MoVOx oxide at the REDOX site to allyl alcohol ( Table 1) [45,46]. In addition, the selective oxidation of allyl alcohol and acrolein under the catalysis of MoO3 may be followed to form acrylic acid [12]. The content of 1–3 wt % of CaO was found to be not conducive to the formation of acrolein and acetol, but is conducive to the formation of allyl alcohol, and the selectivity of allyl alcohol is 27.2 %, 31.6%, 36.3%, respectively. On the one hand, the existence of basic sites may be conducive to the C–C bond and C–O bond of the long chain compounds produced in the fracture reaction, which is conducive to the dehydrating reaction of glycerol to produce alcohol [47]. In terms of catalysis, it is possible that the low content of CaO is conducive to the DODH reaction of glycerol. When the content of CaO was greater than 3 wt %, the selectivity of allyl alcohol decreased significantly while the selectivity of allyl aldehyde and acetol increased. High content of calcium oxide may cover the acid sites and leads to the reduction of acid sites strength and number, resulting in the reduction of glycerol conversion. Similarly, when the CaO content in Mo8V2-Ca2MMT, glycerol conversion decreases significantly, but the selectivity of acrolein and acetol will improve, which may also be related to the addition of a large number of alkaline sites [48]. When the CaO content of Mo8V2-CaMMT catalyst exceeds 3 wt %, the main catalyst may change from MO3 or MoVOx to CaO as the main active site, resulting in the dehydration reaction of glycerol at the acid base site to produce acrolein and acetol. Low selectivity of acrylic acid and 1, 2-propylene glycol were also found in the products. 3.3 Mechanism of resistance to carbon deposition 3.3.1 Stability evaluation of MoV-CaMMT catalyst The catalytic performance of Mo8V2-MMT, Mo8V2-Ca2MMT and Mo8V2-Ca5MMT within 5 h, and the glycerol conversion per hour and the stability of allyl alcohol demonstrates the stability and coking-resistance of the catalyst to a certain extent ( Fig. 5). In this regard, Mo8V2-MMT catalyst achieved the maximum glycerol conversion of 81.6% within 3 h, but the catalytic activity decreased to 24.3 % within a few hours due to the rapid deactivation due to coking. The intercalation of CaO and the presence of calcium species are the reasons for the improved stability of Mo8V2-Ca2MMT and Mo8V2-Ca5MMT catalysts than Mo8V2-MMT catalyst. In addition, the allyl alcohol selectivity of Mo8V2-Ca5MMT catalyst with high CaO content reached a maximum of 39.2 % at 5 h. In the Mo/V catalysts, vanadium and CaO can be used as co-catalyst components to significantly improve the coking-resistance of the catalyst and the stability of the catalyst [49], which may be related to the fact that the doping of CaO species is conducive to the crystallization and dispersion of MO3 or MoVOx particles. However, the existence of basic sites makes glycerol molecules tend to undergo dehydration reaction to produce acrolein and acetol in the catalytic reaction, which also leads to low glycerol conversion and low selectivity of allyl alcohol over MoV-CaMMT catalyst. High content of CaO will cover most of the acidic sites and become the main catalytic active sites, which leads to the deterioration of the catalytic capacity of Mo8V2-Ca5MMT catalyst for the dehydration and oxidation of glycerol. The thermogravimetric analysis of the used catalysts showed that the addition of molybdenum oxide was related to the increase of carbon deposition ( Fig. 6). Among them, the weight loss rate of spent-Mo8V2-MMT was 15.9% during the heating process of 100–800 ℃. Since the temperature heating program was set to stay at 100 ℃ for 30 min to remove most of the water content, the weight loss rate could be regarded as the coking rate of spent-Mo8V2-MMT [50]. The addition of CaO and column support significantly reduced coking rate of the Mo/V catalyst, and the coking rate of Mo8V2-Ca2MMT catalyst was 6.9 %. Similarly, the coking rate of V-Ca2MMT catalyst is 5.3 %, compared with 11.1 % for V-MMT catalyst without CaO. Hence, the addition of vanadium and CaO improves the coking-resistance of molybdenum oxide-based catalyst. 3.3.2 Study on synergistic of calcium and vanadium In order to further explore the coking-resistance of vanadium oxides and CaO, the fresh and used V-Ca2MMT catalyst were characterized by XPS, and the correction was carried out on the basis of C 1s, and the XPS results of C, Ca and V were peak-fitting, respectively ( Fig. 7). Although no significant CO3 2- diffraction peak was found in XRD analysis, the C 1s spectra in XPS confirmed the presence of calcium carbonate in the catalyst. This data also satisfied the FTIR findings. The C–C bond represented by 284.8 eV is an additional carbon source added for correction and the bind energy 287.3 eV regarding CO3 2- is found on its surface, indicating the presence of calcium carbonate on the surface or between layers of the V-CaMMT catalyst [33,38]. The vanadium in the catalyst mainly exists as oxides of V4+ and V5+, which also verifies that the existence of the by-product acrylic acid is the result of the charge transfer between V4+ conversion V5+ and acrolein is adsorbed on the vanadium oxide and oxidized [51]. In addition, the presence of V4+ oxide (VO2) may be the reason that catalysts have good carbon accumulation resistance, so that its REDOX properties can promote the oxidation of carbon deposits into gaseous products easy to leave the surface of the catalyst, and vanadium dioxide itself is not easy to carbon accumulation, so the presence of V4+ is conducive to prevent the accumulation of carbon deposits on the surface of the catalyst [49]. Fig. 7 (c, g) is Ca 2p spectrum [34], Since calcium species in CaO, CaCO3 and Ca(OH)2 are calcium ions, it is difficult to distinguish the binding energy of these three calcium species [38]. However, after the catalytic reaction, it is obvious that the binding energy of 2p1/2 is shifted from 347.0 eV to 346.0 eV, and the binding energy of 2p2/3 is shifted from 351.2 eV to 350.2 eV. This is probably the reaction of CaO with water molecules in glycerol solution or dehydration reaction to form Ca(OH)2. The active sites of V-Ca2MMT catalysts are located at 86.4 ℃, 509.2 ℃ and 598 ℃, which are respectively weak acid sites provided by MMT, strong acid sites provided by acid-activated MMT and vanadium oxides and Mo8V2-Ca2MMT catalyst has two strengths of acid sites (96.2–141.5 ℃, 502.1–670.4 ℃) (Fig. 7 (d, h)) [52,53]. Compared with V-Ca2MMT catalyst, the addition of molybdenum oxide in Mo8V2-Ca2MMT catalyst brought about multiple active sites (141.5 ℃, 670.4 ℃), which may include MoO3, MoVOx and mixed sites of CaO and vanadium oxide. The low impregnation amount of vanadium oxide and the addition of calcium oxide resulted in the weakening of the weak acid and strong acid sites provided by acidified montmorillonite, resulting in the low activity of the catalyst. 4 Conclusion In this study, calcium oxide was added as a cocatalyst not only to prevent the collapse of MMT-lamella under high temperature calcination but also promote the catalytic reaction through improving crystallization of V2O5 and VO2. In addition, the calcium species on the catalyst surface mainly exist in the form of CaO (containing a few CaCO3), and the addition of its basic site will affect the activity and coking-resistance of the catalyst. Low content of CaO was found to be conducive to DODH reaction to produce allyl alcohol but the effect is attenuated by catalysts containing more than 2 wt % CaO, and the dehydration of glycerol at the MoVOx site mainly produces acrolein and acetol. Mo8V2-Ca2MMT had the best catalyst performance with glycerol conversion of 86.5% and allyl alcohol selectivity of 31.6%, compared with undoped CaO catalysts, Mo8V2-Ca2MMT maintains a high conversion rate and stable selectivity within 5 h. Vanadium has been shown to be resistant to coke formation. The synergism of vanadium and CaO improves the coking-resistance of molybdenum oxide-based catalyst. The decrease of catalyst acidity, the presence of VO2 and the stable conversion of V4+ and V5+, and the new weak and strong acid sites formed by MoVOx and CaO play the main role of coking-resistance. But the existence of MoOx created new active sites (MoVOx) in the weak and strong acid sites of the catalyst, which led to the production of another dehydration product (acetol) parallel to allyl alcohol and acrolein. The study of this synergistic effect on solid acid or mixed metal oxide catalysts and its influence can adjust the dispersion and microenvironment of the active site and provide a theoretical basis for the subsequent development of various reaction types of V/Ca based catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Glycerol can be converted to allyl alcohol via deoxydehydration using molybdenum-vanadium, rhenium and iron based catalysts. However, the dehydration causes severe coking at strong acid sites on the surface of catalyst. Molybdenum-vanadium oxide supported on calcium oxide-intercalated montmorillonite (MoV-CaMMT) was prepared by oxalate anion intercalation followed by impregnation. MoV-CaMMT displayed the best catalytic performance of 86.5% glycerol conversion and good stability in 5 h. Correlating the results of XRD, XPS and TG analysis, it can be demonstrated that the addition of CaO in the catalyst preparation is conducive to the crystallization and dispersion of vanadium oxides, and reduces the acid strength, while the presence of a few vanadium dioxide and the stable conversion of V4+ and V5+ are the reasons for enhancing coking-resistance of MoV-CaMMT. Additionally, NH3-TPD analysis proved the coexistence of weak and strong acid sites in MoVOx, which are conducive to the formation of acetol.
coredata.dc:title: Contribution of Ca and V to enhancing coking-resistance and stability of MoV/CaO-intercalated montmorillonite catalyst in deoxydehydration of glycerol
